An Ethereum whale has completely closed a large leveraged position on Aave in a fast de-risking move.

On-chain data shared by Lookonchain shows that wallet 0xa339 sold 5,306 ETH in roughly 20 minutes, worth about $15.76 million, at an average price near $2,970. The sale was used to repay all remaining loans on Aave, removing any liquidation risk.

With the debt cleared in one sweep, the whale withdrew the rest of its collateral â€” around 24,700 ETH, currently valued at $74.41 million â€” effectively shutting down the position for good.

This wasnâ€™t a panic exit. It was the final step in a wider risk-reduction plan that began several days earlier. On December 18, the same wallet sold 20,599 ETH for roughly $59.1 million at prices near $2,869. At its peak, the position was exposed to more than $144 million worth of ETH.

Blockchain data suggests the whale used a looping strategy, where ETH was deposited as collateral, borrowed against, and recycled to increase exposure. By selling during periods of price strength and repaying loans quickly, the trader likely locked in profits while avoiding forced liquidations.

Transaction records from Arkham Intelligence show smooth swaps, fast repayments, and minimal friction â€” a clear example of how large players can now manage risk efficiently using DeFi tools.

While the amount of ETH sold is small compared to daily trading volume, traders are watching closely. Whale exits often influence short-term sentiment, even when they donâ€™t move the market directly.

For now, this looks less like a bearish signal and more like smart risk management. The whale didnâ€™t flee Ethereum â€” it simply removed leverage in an uncertain macro environment.

2025 pushed Ethereumâ€™s Layer 2 ecosystem into its consolidation phase, with liquidity, users, and activity concentrating around a small number of dominant networks.

Here are 6 major Layer 2 trends in 2025 ğŸ§µğŸ‘‡ 
1/ Layer 2 activity consolidated sharply.

While the number of L2s continued to grow, meaningful usage did not.

New rollups saw activity collapse after incentive programs ended, reinforcing a power-law distribution where only a handful captured sustained users and liquidity. 
2/ @Base emerged as the clear leader

Base dominated across TVL, active users, transactions, and DEX volume throughout 2025.

TVL grew from ~$3.1B in January to a peak above $5.6B, representing ~47% of L2 DeFi TVL, driven by Coinbase's distribution. 
3/ Enterprise L2s validated the rollup-as-distribution model

2025 marked the rise of the â€œenterprise rollup.â€

Kraken (INK), Uniswap (Unichain), Sony (Soneium), and Robinhood (Arbitrum) all adopted L2 infrastructure, highlighting that distribution now drive new launches.
4/ Ethereum reasserted dominance in data availability

After early-year spikes driven by short-lived rollups, alternative DA usage declined as incentives faded.

Postâ€“EIP-4844 optimization made Ethereum blobs the preferred DA layer for high-activity rollups. 
5/ Decentralization progress remained limited

Despite years of roadmaps, most L2s still rely on centralized sequencers, upgrade keys, and trusted operators. 
6/ Bitcoin L2s failed to gain traction

Bitcoin L2 TVL fell over 74% YTD, while BTCFi remained a fraction of Ethereumâ€™s scale.

Despite continued fundraising,  Bitcoin L2s failed to attract sustained builders or users, leaving the sector without a clear catalyst. 
sum/ 2025 showed Layer 2s maturing into infrastructure businesses defined by distribution, not experimentation. Liquidity and users continue to concentrate, while most chains struggle to justify their existence.
